text:
Human rights 'not off the table' in discussions with China, says Devon MP By WMNKLangston | Posted: October 22, 2015 Hugo Swire Human rights 'not off the table' in discussions with China, says Devon MP X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Strengthened trade links with China do not present the UK with a “binary choice” between “greater economic co-operation and human rights”, a Devon MP has claimed. 
Foreign minister and MP for East Devon Hugo Swire said “nothing is off the table” in Britain’s discussions with the superpower and it would raise the issue of rights “without fear”. 
His comments came during an urgent debate in the House of Commons, which saw MPs from all parties press the Government on its human rights dialogue with China. 
The session followed the announcement of £30 billion worth of deals with Chinese investors during the state visit by President Xi Jinping. 
The Prime Minister has come under increasing pressure to justify the UK’s trade relationship with the country in light of its poor human rights record. 
The visit has coincided with a number of protests by human rights groups. And yesterday, MPs quizzed Mr Swire about the Government’s efforts to broach the topic. 
Responding to their concerns, the former Northern Ireland minister stated that building a “strong relationship” between the nations was allowing ministers “to discuss all issues”. 
“No issue, including human rights, is off the table,” he said. 
“We certainly do not see this visit as presenting a binary choice between greater economic co-operation and human rights, as some would have us do. I reject that utterly. 
“There are things that we take for granted in this country. We should be ever-vigilant of the fact that others around the world do not enjoy those same liberties. 
“We should be jealous in guarding the privileges that we enjoy and do everything we can to export them to countries that are less fortunate.” 
Among the high profile deals announced this week was a £6 billion investment in the Hinkley Point C nuclear reactor. The project is expected to create around 25,000 over the course of its construction and day to day running. 
Officials also signed deals for BP to sell £6.5 billion worth of natural gas to Chinese firms over the next 20 years, and reached an agreement on sustainable development goals. 
Fiona Bruce, the chairman of the Conservative Party Human Rights Commission who tabled the urgent debate, said she recognised “the significance” of Britain’s business links with China. 
But she said dialogue on human rights, freedom of thought, speech and assembly, and the rule of law must also be placed “at the centre” of the relationship.
